paragraphs.text: US economy: Why I'm optimistic about growth in 2015.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Could 2015 be the breakout year for the economy?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Last week we got very joyful news
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: All of this is good news as we ring in the new year
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And the best may be yet to come
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So why is the economy finally shifting into a higher gear?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This isn' t a story of government-directed growth or stimulus spending
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It's the opposite
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Washington's role in the economy is starting to shrink after years of Obama administration activism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The private sector is starting to take over
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The growth was propelled by a big rise in business investment, up nearly 9 percent; personal consumption, up 3.2 percent; and exports, up 4.5 percent
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Government spending, which is a negative for the economy, grew by 4.4 percent, thanks to a big rise in military spending
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: domestic spending is still restrained
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The news was so good that even the threat that the Fed will now have an excuse to raise interest rates hasn't deterred the bulls on Wall Street
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Here is the case for optimism going forward
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: First
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: a huge factor in the economic rebound has been the fall in energy costs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As the price of oil has fallen from $105 a barrel this summer to closer $70 by September,(and at the end of December it was at $53) the cost of oil imports has tumbled
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Imports fell by nearly 2 percent
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: this alone added almost 0.2 percentage points to GDP growth
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Even that greatly understates the economic windfall from cheap energy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Production costs fall when energy costs do
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the supply of American-produced non-oil and gas products, such as manufactured goods, rises when gas is cheap
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Gas prices should continue to fall
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the good-news story rolls on
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the addition to GDP from energy should be even higher
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Thank you, Texas and Oklahoma and North Dakota
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: And thank you, fracking
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Second
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: businesses are clearly feeling less trepidation about investing
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: some of the wet blanket of Obama's anti-business, anti-shareholder agenda has dissipated as the Republican Congress repels his worst ideas: cap-and-trade, minimum wage hikes, new taxes on the energy industry and massive new spending initiatives out of Washington
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Gridlock now looks to be built into the political system for the next two years, and in many ways that's reassuring
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Third
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: government spending has fallen a lot more than people think
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Despite the boost in military spending in the last quarter, the biggest story of the U.S  economy over the last three years has been the retrenchment of government spending
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Federal spending has fallen from 24.4 percent of GDP in 2009 and 23.4 percent of GDP in 2010 to 21 percent of GDP in 2014
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Even better news is that in the fourth quarter of 2014, federal spending as a share of GDP fell to below 20 percent, according to a new analysis by Dan Clifton of Strategas, an economic policy consulting firm
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: This is creating an anti-Keynesian boost to growth, because the government is taking fewer private sector resources each month
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The 4 percentage points less of GDP that the government is spending means 4 percent more GDP for private businesses and families to spend
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That's close to $700 billion a year more for private investment and construction and spending
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This, by the way, shows the foolhardiness of the Keynesian notion of a government-spending free lunch
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Five years ago the Obama economics team was talking about multiplier effects from higher federal outlays -- the stimulus bill spent $830 billion-- that would juice the economy with even more private spending
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It never happened
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even President Obama's own economic analysis found the economy grew more slowly than it would have without the government debt- financed spending
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The real effect of government spending is to crowd out private spending
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A final reason for optimism is that the incoming class of Republican governors and conservative state legislators across the country should mean more growth policies coming out of state capitals
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: At least a dozen governors from Massachusetts to Illinois to Tennessee are talking about tax cuts to create jobs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: even if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we don't get tax reform at the federal level
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: states should be providing an additional tax cut stimulus
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Skeptics will say that Obama's executive actions on climate change, immigration, energy policy and so on will continue to be a restraint on growth
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That's for sure
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This recovery from recession is still nearly $2 trillion behind where we should would be if we had a Reagan-paced boom
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This is still one of the most anemic recoveries
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: though it is belatedly picking up steam
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It's also true that wages are still flat for most workers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the big challenge for the economy is raising productivity so Americans get a well- deserved pay raise
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As 2014 comes to a close, here's where we are
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Interest rates are as low as they've been in 40 years
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: inflation is tame, thanks to the surge in oil and gas output
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: corporate profits remain high
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The rest of the world economy, from Germany to Japan to Russia, is a debacle
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But that's all the more reason to bet on the USA in 2015
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: no, Mr  President, you didn't build that
paragraphs.label: assumption
